author: Mohammed Iqbal
text:
The symposium on Women’s Day was to be held on High Court premises

A section of lawyers had taken strong exception to the choice of the Delhi High Court as the venue of the symposium.

In a major embarrassment, a lawyers’ body affiliated to the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh was on Tuesday forced to shift the venue of its symposium marking the International Women’s Day from the Delhi High Court to a cultural centre here after the High Court withdrew the permission granted earlier to organise the event on its premises.

High Court Chief Justice G. Rohini, invited as chief guest to the symposium meant to celebrate women’s empowerment and discuss “legal, social and political justice for women,” did not attend the programme.

Controversy

A controversy had erupted over the allotment of the High Court’s A-block lobby to the Adhivakta Parishad, Delhi, for holding the event. A section of lawyers had taken strong exception to the choice of the High Court as the venue and raised questions about the court premises playing host for events organised by private bodies and sitting judges participating in them.

After the High Court administration informed the Adhivakta Parishad of the withdrawal of permission citing “security concerns,” the organisers shifted the event to the Malviya Smriti Bhavan in Central Delhi. Adhivakta Parishad vice-president Suman Chauhan told The Hindu that the lawyers’ body had decided to change the venue due to “some constraints.”

Adhivakta Parishad wanted to organise event to mark International Women’s Day
title: Delhi HC withdraws nod for symposium of RSS lawyers’ body
